reviewText: A colour remake of "It's a Date", NANCY GOES TO RIO (1950) is a relatively minor entry in Jane Powell's cycle of sunny MGM musicals, but I've always found it to be a particular delight.  Just like so many of her roles, Powell plays a young woman with showbiz dreams and a special knack for romantic complications.Aching to follow her mother, legendary Broadway star Frances Elliott (Ann Sothern) in the "family business", Nancy Barklay (Powell) unexpectedly lands the lead role in a new musical that her mother is also considering.  Sworn to secrecy, Nancy boards a cruiseliner to Rio to join her mother at their holiday house, but also to squeeze in some early preparation for her role.  Complications arise when fellow passenger Paul Berton (Barry Sullivan) overhears Nancy reciting the part of an abandoned young wife and expectant mother...and believes the act!  The plot spirals into high farce when Nancy assumes that Paul has proposed...but when he meets Nan's mother shortly after docking in Rio, promptly falls in love with HER!Co-starring Carmen Miranda, Louis Calhern and Scotty Beckett, NANCY GOES TO RIO serves up much of the same fun and cast dynamics as Powell's earlier delight, "A Date with Judy".  Powell is once again paired with Beckett as her ungainly but devoted boyfriend, and Carmen Miranda flashes across the screen with two colourful musical numbers.  Ann Sothern charms as Powell's mother; looking every inch the glamorous Broadway diva in her Helen Rose costumes.  Songs include "Shine On Harvest Moon", "Magic is the Moonlight", "Time and Time Again", "Yipsee-I-O", "Baio (Ca-Room' Pa Pa)", "Love Is Like This", "Embraceable You", "Musetta's Waltz", and "Nancy's Goin' to Rio".
Title: N/A

reviewText: The basic plot centers around the daughter (Jane Powell) going to Rio for a job and her mother, Ann Southern (who looks and behaves more like her sister), trying to thwart a "masher" whom she thinks is after her daughter.  Carmen Miranda provies some wonderful scenes in her second of only two MGM movies.  Watch for the umbrella number!  It's simple over-the-top lavishness and downright  craziness is what made her the highest-paid female star of the 40's!  Basically, the movie is enjoyable, but the plot (and the scenery--the backdrop of Rio from the hotel room is hilarious to look at) are rather contrived, even for a musical.
summary: Enjoyable, but Plot is Definitely Iffy
Title: N/A

reviewText: This glittering musical is highlighted by dynamic  performances.  The Barklays are a three-generation musical theatre family--grandpa (Louis Calhern), his daughter (Ann Southern) and his granddaughter, Nancy.(Jane Powell)After closing her current musical hit, Ann Southern decides to travel to Rio with grandpa to study for her new play set in Brazil.  Nancy remains behind to fulfill committments in summer theatre activities.  Ann's producer has promised to see Nancy in her summer stock production and he is so pleased with her performance that he decides to use her in the part he had planned for her mother.  Thrilled and dazed, Nancy decides to take a cruise to Rio to join her mother, unaware that she was offered the part first.Matters are further complicated on the cruise when Carmen Miranda mistakes Nancy for being in a family way and she asks her boss, Barry Sullivan, to take Nancy under his wing.  Nancy mistakes his attention as romantic and falls head over heals for him--a fate shared later by her mother when they arrive in Rio.  Riotous un-doings add to the delight of the film as mother and daughter vie for the same part and the same man.The musical numbers are dazzling.  Ann Southern leads out with the beautiful TIME AND TIME AGAIN.  The Barklays join forces for a heartwarming SHINE ON HARVEST MOON.  Miss Miranda gives us a rousing YIPSEE-I-O and CA-ROOM! PA-PA.  Jane Powell sparkles in some of her finest screen work in MAGIC IS THE MOONLIGHT, the lovely MUSETTA'S WALTZ and the sensational finale LOVE IS LIKE THIS.Highly recommended for an evening of fun and really good music.
Title: N/A

reviewText: (the review title is the name of a musical number in this film)Nancy Goes to Rio may not be the very best musical ever; but then again MGM standards of quality were so high that this film is still a fine motion picture! They could have edited down the film by a couple of minutes here and there; but the acting and those wonderful musical numbers were so good that it all kept me curious to see how everything would work out. The choreography and the cinematography reflect a lot of careful planning; and the musical score enhances the film as well.Nancy Barklay (Jane Powell) is all excited to have her boyfriend Scotty (Scotty Beckett) meet her mother Frances Elliott (Ann Sothern), a most successful veteran stage actress who is appearing in the final performance of a great Broadway play. After the show is over there's a huge party for Frances back at her swanky New York apartment; and Frances' father Gregory Elliott (Louis Calhern) hams it up so he can be surrounded by young women--all in good fun, of course. However, there's another guest at the party, Ricardo Domingos (Fortunio Bonanova) from Brazil; he wants Frances to star in a stage play he just wrote. While Ricardo is impressed by Frances, just by chance he happens to also meet Nancy--and the trouble and hijinks start when Ricardo likes Nancy enough to give her the part instead of her mother! Family friend and director Arthur Barrett (Glenn Anders) tells Nancy not to breathe a word of this so they can handle the leading lady change diplomatically.Frances and her father Gregory are already in Rio when Nancy herself arrives. But before Nancy can even get to Rio by ship, the plot thickens. Interestingly, during Nancy's voyage to Brazil there's a huge mix-up while she's practicing her lines to play the leading lady. Paul Berten (Barry Sullivan) overhears Nancy rehearsing her lines about how she's "going to have the baby anyway" and Paul jumps to the conclusion that Nancy is pregnant for real! He tells his business partner Marina Rodrigues (Carmen Miranda) about Nancy's "situation" and they try to help her in any way they can. This leads to a few funny scenes aboard ship when it comes to what Nancy should eat at the dinner table and more.Of course there's much more to the plot than this but I won't write more to avoid giving away spoilers! Suffice it to say that the rest of the film shows how all the issues and misunderstandings work out when everyone is finally in Brazil; and the musical numbers are terrific.I highly recommend this film for fans of the actors in it; and people who enjoy five star musicals will not be disappointed.
Title: N/A

reviewText: The costumes and scenery are so brilliant and colorful in this film.  It's a very entertaining musical.  Jane Powell and Anne Southern are cast perfectly as mother daughter in it.  It's feast for the eys to see.

reviewText: This is a great story and Ann Southern is beautiful and a great actress.  I love her "Macie" movies too.  Jane Powell is very good in this movie, ...trying to be so mature, and her love interest through misunderstandings it priceless.  If you like lots of singing, you'll enjoy this one - You don't have to worry if you children watch (hear)it, but they probably won't know what's going on.
